Subject: [Outreach] [Email] [Out] Your AI procurement mandate is already gaining external validation
Description:
From: "Ria Shrivastava" <ria.shrivastava@zycusasia.com>
To: "Tareq Amin" <tareq.amin@humain.ai>

Dear Mr. Tareq,

Ever since you set the mandate for Humain to become a proof point of AI-led enterprise execution — not just AI experimentation — your team has been moving with impressive urgency.

Given that direction, I thought you’d want to hear this firsthand:

Zycus — the platform your team is currently evaluating — has just been named a 2025 Customers’ Choice in Gartner’s “Voice of the Customer” for Source-to-Pay Suites.

This recognition is not analyst opinion — it’s based entirely on verified enterprise buyers who have already made the AI shift. Highlights:
4.6 / 5 overall rating (67 reviews as of June ‘25)

95% willingness to recommend — highest among competitors

Consistent 4.4+ across Product, Deployment, Support

It reinforces one thing: Your instinct was right. Humain isn’t just exploring another tool — you’re aligning with what top-performing organizations already trust under similar pressure.

If helpful, I can send you a single-page “Leadership Brief” summarizing how other PIF-backed entities are implementing AI-led procurement at scale.

Kind Regards,
Ria Shrivastava
Business Development | APAC
Gartner, and Forrester Ranked Leader: Source-to-Pay Software

If you'd like me to stop sending you emails, please click here

Subject: [Outreach] [Email] [Out] Validation you may want before formalizing your AI procurement proposal
Description:
From: "Ria Shrivastava" <ria.shrivastava@zycusasia.com>
To: "Saejong Lee" <saejong@humain.ai>

Dear Saejong,

You’ve taken a structured, architecture-first approach in evaluating how Zycus can anchor Humain’s AI procurement framework — which is exactly what a mandate of this scale deserves.

Given that, I thought you’d want to know:
Zycus has just been recognized as a 2025 Customers’ Choice in Gartner’s Voice of the Customer for Source-to-Pay Suites — based entirely on deployment feedback from real enterprise customers.

Key proof points:
4.6 / 5 overall rating (67 reviews as of June 2025)

95% willingness to recommend — highest among S2P vendors

Consistent 4.4+ ratings across Product Capability, Deployment, and Support

Rather than waiting until late-stage approval cycles, I suggest we formalize the proposal track now — so you have:
✅ Deployment architecture options (Saudi-hosted / hybrid)
 ✅ Integration blueprint aligned to your SAP/Oracle stack
 ✅ Security documentation ready for internal routing



Would it be reasonable to align on timelines for the RFP/proposal submission process so we can structure materials in your preferred format?

Happy to move at your pace — just let me know how you’d like to proceed.

Kind Regards,
Ria Shrivastava
Business Development | APAC
Gartner, and Forrester Ranked Leader: Source-to-Pay Software

Subject: Build an org chart and map all the key contacts
Prospect's gone cold ? No inbound since last 14 days
Get clarity on the evaluation stages and influence the process
Quick Sync x Zycus
Description:
-- Avoma Note Start --
 Avoma - : Quick Sync x Zycus <> October 01, 2025 at 11:30 AM UTC
 Avoma Meeting: https://app.avoma.com/meetings/95a8cc89-b173-4e74-8e27-f9bd25b2decc/notes
## Participants

  * Zycus: Ria Shrivastava, Dan Quinn

  * Humain: Majid Abdulelah

## Key Takeaways

  * Procurement focus shifted from HR to procurement; exploring white-label capabilities for a ChatGPT-like interface integrated in enterprise UI.
  * Strong requirement for automated supplier onboarding with API-based validation of CR, tax IDs and trade licenses per Saudi regulations to prevent fake companies.
  * Aim to implement a fully automated vendor onboarding process with prepopulated data, AI-driven extraction from VAT certificates, and staged due diligence.
  * Plan to compile security and architecture requirements into a simple Excel matrix (yes/no plus descriptions) and share internally within this week.
  * Acknowledged urgency due to PIF-funded startup status, audit compliance gaps and pending budget approvals necessitating rapid solution deployment.

## Action Items

  * Majid Abdulelah

    * Hold an internal meeting with the security team to gather their vendor validation requirements and send Zycus an Excel sheet table of yes/no answers with descriptions
  * Dan Quinn

    * Send Majid an invite with details for the AI in procurement networking lunch at the Riyadh Hilton on Thursday

## White Labeling & UI Customization

  * Majid inquired about white label capabilities to customize platform branding.
  * Dan confirmed support for custom logos, color schemes, and SSO integration.
  * Majid emphasized need for a ChatGPT-style UI with integrated procurement ‘buy’ functionality.

## AI Chatbot Integration for Procurement

  * Majid outlined approval flow: line-manager approvals followed by procurement manager decision.
  * Majid described user interaction: typing a purchase request triggers automated PR initiation.
  * Dan confirmed availability via Microsoft Teams bot or web interface trained on organizational policies.

## Procurement Compliance Requirements

  * Validation required for CR, commercial registration, tax, VAT, CAT and other Saudi government procurement details
  * Strict verification needed to prevent fake companies entering system using random numbers

## Vendor Onboarding Data Requirements

  * Majid asked how Zycus retrieves and validates Saudi vendor data like CR, tax and VAT.
  * Majid stressed compliance risk if fake companies register with random numbers.
  * Majid requested details on automated vs. manual data entry in onboarding flow.

## Security & Compliance Validation

  * Majid raised concern over vendors submitting false data and its impact on compliance.
  * Majid sought clarification on security measures to prevent unauthorized or counterfeit supplier entries.
  * Majid asked what due diligence Zycus applies to vendor registrations, including existing suppliers.

## Integration with Validation Authorities

  * Plan to integrate via APIs with local authorities for real-time trade license and personal ID validation

## Regional Deployment & Existing Clients

  * Majid inquired about Zycus’s current client presence in Saudi Arabia.
  * Dan highlighted Majid Al Fatim Abdul Latif Jamil and upcoming CBRE go-live.
  * Dan noted recent investments in local hosting for KSA and UAE to accelerate regional growth.

## Automated Supplier Onboarding Process

  * Majid requested a simplified, fully automated end-vendor onboarding process for Abdul Latif Jamil.
  * Majid asked about time required for a company to self-register with AI-driven prepopulation.
  * Majid confirmed interest in prepopulated profiles via OCR and AI extraction of supplier documents.

## Automation of Vendor Onboarding

  * CEO mandate: simplify and fully automate end-to-end vendor onboarding process

## AI Assistance in Bid Proposal Process

  * AI will auto-generate technical questionnaires, score supplier responses with weighted criteria, and log any SME overrides in the audit trail

## Audit Challenges & Investment Urgency

  * Majid reported manual procurement tasks causing major audit flags and organizational chaos.
  * Majid highlighted PIF-backed startup status and upcoming $10,000,000,000 Amazon investment.
  * Majid emphasized need for rapid implementation pending final budget and resource approval.

## Follow-up Meeting

  * Majid mentioned the possibility of being pulled away for a meeting in Kuwait on Wednesday but intends to be in Riyadh that Wednesday as well and agrees to plan to share details and confirm attendance for the Thursday event.
  * Dan Quinn mentioned he will be in Riyadh next Wednesday and Thursday (relative to the meeting date 2025-10-01) and invited Majid to a networking lunch at the Riyadh Hilton on Thursday from about 12 to 3 PM with an offer to meet face to face on Wednesday as well.

 
-- Avoma Note End --

Subject: Quick Sync x Zycus
Description:
-- Avoma Note Start --
 Avoma - : Quick Sync x Zycus <> October 01, 2025 at 6:00 AM UTC
 Avoma Meeting: https://app.avoma.com/meetings/e6820017-a406-4922-8650-68402beb8fe9/notes
## Participants

  * Zycus: Ria Shrivastava, Dan Quinn

  * Humain: Majid Abdulelah

## Key Takeaways

  * Dan aims to qualify this opportunity as real before scheduling an in-person meeting in Riyadh on Wednesday or Thursday next week.
  * Meeting with Majid was rescheduled to 2:30 local time, equating to 1:30 PM Dan’s time for a 15–20 minute discussion.
  * Availability windows were identified as 11:00–12:00 and after 15:00 Dan’s time, with a request to avoid back-to-back bookings.
  * Encouragingly, Majid entered the meeting already considering Zycus’s procurement solution, signaling genuine interest in the project.
  * Next step involves waiting for Majid’s CEO update and offering alternative time slots if no response is received within a few hours.

## Action Items

  * Ria Shrivastava

    * Suggest meeting slots (today or tomorrow) once Majid responds, based on her calendar availability.
    * Call Majid in a few hours if no update is received to nudge for meeting time options.
  * Dan Quinn

    * Prepare for a potential in-person meeting with Majid in Riyadh next Wednesday or Thursday morning if the opportunity qualifies.
    * Review personal diary to avoid back-to-back meetings when scheduling the follow-up call.
    * If Majid does not respond, follow up with him and propose a couple of time options for the rescheduled meeting.
  * Majid Abdulelah

    * Speak with CEO to gather procurement details and then propose a new meeting time slot (e.g., 2:30) to Zycus.

## Opportunity Qualification and Project Update

  * Plan to gather further insight to decide whether to qualify the opportunity after Majid’s update.
  * Majid will discuss procurement details with the CEO and provide project scope and status updates before reconvening.
  * Uncertainty on whether the opportunity can be qualified for this quarter or needs to roll into the last quarter.
  * Majid approached the discussion with Zycus in mind, indicating existing interest in Zycus’s solution.

## Travel and Availability

  * Trip schedule may swap Wednesday for a Kuwait visit, though Thursday remains tentatively available pending final confirmation.
  * Dan Quinn will be in Riyadh next Wednesday and Thursday with some free time in the morning and afternoon.
  * Current day availability: free until 11:00 his time (12:00 my), open from 12:00 to 13:00 his time (02:00 my), busy 13:00–14:00 his time, then free after 15:00 my time.

## Meeting Reschedule with CEO

  * Majid requests moving the meeting to 14:30 local time as he is about to meet the CEO and needs to discuss procurement details.
  * Offers flexibility to meet slightly earlier or later if required and expresses willingness to fit additional time options.
  * Dan confirms 14:30 local equates to 13:30 his time and he can allocate 15–20 minutes before his 14:00 call.

## Meeting Rescheduling

  * Meeting moved to 14:30 Majid time, 13:30 Dan time
  * Timing is flexible with options to schedule earlier or later slots
  * Call duration limited to 15–20 minutes due to Dan's 14:00 call

## Follow-up and Communication Strategy

  * Ria to monitor the calendar and propose alternate slots for continuation if today's schedule becomes unfeasible.
  * Dan advises avoiding back-to-back scheduling and plans to defer prep until Majid's update arrives.
  * Agree to reach out with alternative time options if Majid cannot confirm the proposed 14:30 slot.
  * Team to wait for Majid’s follow-up post-CEO meeting; Ria to call him in a few hours if no response arrives.

## Post-Meeting Strategies

  * Allow Majid to meet CEO first and await update before proposing next steps
  * If no response in a few hours, Ria to call and send a general nudge

 
-- Avoma Note End --
